Nutrition Calculator EFSA Health Claims 
Summary The NORtritious project, initiated by Fremtidsmat, aims to assist food producers such as Bama, Coop, Melk.no, Nortura, and others in creating healthy and sustainable food products. Fremtidsmat seeks to simplify and improve the accuracy of developing food products that meet multiple EFSA nutritional claims simultaneously. In this project, we developed a full-stack web application for the NORtritious platform using React and ASP .NET Core. The central component of this application is the nutrition calculator, which is designed to assist food producers in creating healthier and more sustainable products. The project focused on implementing membership functionalities, improving the accuracy of nutritional claims, improving usability, and integrating EFSA Health Claims from the ground up. These improvements will help the product development process of the NORtritious platform, as well as future development.  
Foreword This bachelor thesis has been dedicated to the development of the NORtritious platform, a web application and its nutrition calculator, aimed at assisting food producers in creating healthier food products. We would like to express our gratitude our supervisors, Associate Professor Way Kiat Bong and Baifan Zhou for the guidance throughout this project. We also extend our thanks to Fremtidsmat and its members. During the course of this project, we have gained valuable experience in full-stack development, user-driven design, and more. The full contents of the report are as follows; Part 1 provides an introduction to the project. In Part 2, methodology is discussed. The application documentation is presented in Part 3. 1 Introduction 1.1 About the Project The NORtritious platform is designed to assist food producers in developing healthier food products by helping them meet speciﬁc health standards like the Keyhole label (will be referred to as Nøkkelhullet throughout) and EFSA Nutritional Claims. Initially, the project focused on building the frontend of the website and accurately verifying these claims. Over time, our work has expanded NORtritious into a full web application, incorporating both the existing nutrition calculator and additional EFSA Health Claims. By developing both the frontend and backend, we've aimed to make the platform more reliable and accessible for users. The development took place from February 2025 to May 2025 and included, among other activities, user testing with a nutritional expert to gather feedback and make improvements. 1.2 Project Background NORtritious was created to support food companies in producing healthier options by ensuring their products comply with established health standards such as Nøkkelhullet and EFSA Nutritional Claims. Recognizing the need for a dependable tool to manage and verify these standards, Fremtidsmat and OsloMet launched the NORtritious project. The web application, with the Nutritional Calculator at its core, plays a crucial role in helping producers navigate these requirements ecectively. 1.3 Client, Project Contact, Project Group Client: OsloMet and Fremtidsmat Table 1 Project contacts Name Title Mail Baifan Zhou Internal Supervisor baifan.zhou@oslomet.no  Way Kiat Bong Internal Supervisor wayki@oslomet.no

1.4 Goals  The goal for this project was to ﬁrst integrate the existing calculator into the new web application, build the web app comprehensively, then ﬁx existing bugs of the nutrition calculator if found. This application is designed for food producers and researchers speciﬁcally. Through usage of the nutritional calculator, they can check their food products for compliance with Nøkkelhullet, EFSA Nutritonal claims, and EFSA Health claims. The project aims for the following: 1.4.1 Main Goals 1. Integrate Existing Calculator into the new Web Application  • Move the existing calculator into the new web application 2. Development of Full-Stack Web Application • Create both the user interface and backend systems to ensure seamless functionality and user interaction for the platform. More details on The Web app in chapter 1.3.2.  3. Role-Based Users • Users should be able to create an account with a role as either a Food Producer or a Researcher.

•  Food Producers should be able to add, edit and delete products. Researchers should only be allowed to view products. Lastly Administrators can edit and delete products. 4. Implement EFSA Health Claims: • Implement EFSA health claims, with focus on vitamins and minerals. 5. Bug Fixes and UI Improvements: • Address existing bugs and UI issues • Fix existing bugs with Nøkkelhullet and EFSA Nutritional Claims, which contains code from previous iterations of the project. 1.4.2 Details on the Web App Role-Based User Functionality: • Implement user authentication based on roles. The deﬁned three roles are Administrator, Food Producer, and Researcher. • Administrators: Can update and delete products. • Food Producers: Can add, update, and delete their own products. • Researchers: Can read the content of products but cannot make changes. Calculator Page: • Allow users to input product details, calculate nutritional values and check for compliance with Nøkkelhullet, EFSA Nutritional Claims, and EFSA Health Claims. Product Page: • For Researchers: Displays listing of all existing products. • For Food Producers: Displays listing of all their own existing products. • Includes ﬁltering options and search functionality. Settings Page: • Allows personalization of user proﬁles, including uploading images (company logo), changing password, and enabling two-factor authentication.

2 Methodology In this chapter, we describe the methodology that guided the development of our project. We began by outlining the startup phase, where we deﬁned the project’s goals and initial direction. The project plan detailed our timeline and milestones, while the agile development approach allowed us to work ﬂexibly and adapt to feedback. We explain the tools and programming languages we used to support both development and collaboration. A project diary was maintained to document weekly activities and reﬂections. To ensure quality, we conducted unit testing of backend components and user testing to evaluate usability and functionality. Finally, we addressed ethical considerations related to data privacy, user responsibility, and transparency in development. 2.1 Startup Our mandate for further development of the NORtritious calculator began with an initial knowledge transfer of the work of previous groups, as well as what the expectations for our part in the project were. To initiate the process, we held a meeting with one of our supervisors, where we were given an overview of the calculator’s current functionalities and discussed the scope of our contributions. During this meeting, we also signed the necessary contracts to formalize our involvement.  Next, we arranged another meeting with both supervisors, laying out in more detail the direction of the project and what should be implemented. Subsequently, this became the foundation for the development plan and pre-project report, ensuring that we had a clear understanding of the tasks ahead.  As part of our onboarding process, we familiarized ourselves with the existing codebase and gained access to the GitLab repository, where the project was actively managed. We transferred the codebase to our own GitHub repository and made sure it was properly set up on our systems, enabling seamless collaboration. Additionally, we received documentation outlining the EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) requirements for nutrition and health claims, along with guidance on where to ﬁnd relevant data sources.

14 / 126  
These materials were essential for understanding regulatory constraints and ensuring compliance throughout development. 2.2 Project Plan Recognizing that priorities and tasks might shift over the course of development, we created a Gantt diagram to provide a structured yet ﬂexible timeline for our work. This diagram was built upon the development plan outlined in the productivity software tool Notion, as discussed in Chapter 2.3, and served as a high-level visual roadmap of the project. It outlined the entire development period, breaking it down into phases, milestones, and key events. The Gantt diagram provided a clear overview of the project’s progression, showing when each phase would start and end. It also incorporated key moments such as user testing, allowing us to allocate time for gathering feedback and implementing necessary improvements. Additionally, it accounted for important events like contract signing, pre-project planning, and the ﬁnal presentation of our product. 
 Figure 1 Development Plan (Gantt) Figure 1 illustrates our ﬁve development phases, which are detailed further in Section 2.3.3. Working in a task-based Scrumban manner, the structure of our plan allowed for ﬂexibility. If certain tasks were completed ahead of schedule, we could transition seamlessly into subsequent tasks, ensuring that progress remained steady and, whenever possible, ahead of schedule rather than behind. This also created room to handle unforeseen challenges or bottlenecks without breaking up the overall workﬂow.

15 / 126  
By combining the structured overview of the Gantt diagram with the ﬂexibility of Scrumban, we maintained a balance between long-term planning and iterative development. This approach allowed us to respond to changes while keeping the project on track and ensuring that each phase was completed in a timely manner. 2.3 Agile Development In managing our project, we adopted an Agile development methodology that combined elements of both Scrum and Kanban, a hybrid known as Scrumban. This combination allowed us to leverage the strengths of both methodologies to maintain ﬂexibility while ensuring steady progress and structure. Below, we discuss how we utilized Scrum, Kanban, and Sprint Cycles in our project. 2.3.1 Scrum Scrum is an Agile framework that provides structure through deﬁned roles and events (Schwaber & Sutherland, 2020). It focuses on iterative development, continuous improvement, and regular reﬂection. Its beneﬁts include deﬁning a clear structure for roles (such as Scrum Master and Product Owner) and events (such as Sprint Planning) which provide clarity and help ensure the team is aligned with the project’s goals. Scrum also ensures steady progress by dividing the project into Sprints, normally 2-4 weeks. Lastly, it is a framework which encourages frequent retrospectives to discuss what is working well, and what needs improving, as well as daily stand-up meetings for closely monitored progress. 2.3.2 Kanban Kanban is a visual task management methodology that emphasizes continuous delivery, workﬂow eciciency and ﬂexibility (Bhaskar, 2024). The main beneﬁt of using Kanban includes allowing for dynamic adjustment of tasks as priorities change, making it ideal for projects with shifting requirements, which we experienced occasionally. Secondly, Kanban helps visualize the progress of tasks through dicerent stages, enabling teams to identify bottlenecks and optimize their workﬂow. Kanban also manages tasks in smaller, incremental steps, which promotes faster delivery and reduces delays.

2.3.3 A Scrumban Approach 
 Figure 2 Phases as set up in Notion Overview of Phases: • Phase 1: Project Setup and Backend Foundation (Weeks 6–7) We set up the basic structure of the project, including the tools we used to build the website. We also put in place the initial security measures. • Phase 2: Core Functionalities and Initial Testing (Weeks 8–11) We worked on the main functions, like logging in and managing products. We tested these features to make sure they worked well. • Phase 3: Advanced Functionalities and User Interaction (Weeks 12–15) We added detailed product information and user account features, ensuring that users had the right access. We also tested how everything worked together. • Phase 4: Quality Assurance, Final Enhancements, and User Testing (Weeks 16–17) We checked the overall usability of the system, ﬁxing any issues and ﬁnishing our documentation. • Phase 5: Final Reporting and Submission (Weeks 18–20) We prepared the ﬁnal report and documentation, making sure everything was ready for submission.

17 / 126  
We structured our development plan into ﬁve phases as shown in Figure 2, each broken down into detailed subtasks. This not only allowed us to maintain focus on the high-level goals but also ensured that every aspect of the project was covered in smaller, manageable tasks. Using Notion, we organized these phases and tasks in a way that enabled us to clearly delegate responsibilities, set deadlines, and track the completion percentage of each subtask. This approach ensured that all team members had a clear view of the project's progress throughout its duration. A key feature of our approach was the use of bi-weekly sprints. Given that some team members also have signiﬁcant side commitments, a two-week sprint cycle provided the necessary time to balance both the project and personal responsibilities. This extended timeframe allowed us to deliver incremental results while maintaining ﬂexibility to adjust our goals based on emerging needs or unforeseen challenges. 
 Figure 3 Delegable tasks belonging to phases as set up in Notion Notion played a crucial role in managing our Scrumban process. Through its intuitive and visual interface, we could:

18 / 126  
• Create and track tasks: Each phase was organized in tasks, and we could assign team members to speciﬁc responsibilities, ensuring accountability. • Monitor progress: By tracking completion percentages, we were able to get real-time insights into how each task was progressing, and where adjustments or additional resources might be needed. • Prioritize and adjust tasks: We could move tasks between phases as priorities shifted or new information became available, enabling us to respond quickly and adapt our workﬂow. The task phases followed a ﬂow from Not Started, through to On-going and eventually Done. Should there be something holding up the progression of one task, like for instance incomplete dependencies, we would place the task in the Waiting phase. We also held weekly meetings with our project supervisors and conducted weekly Sprint Planning meetings, the details of which are presented in Chapter 2.5. The need for daily sprints was found to be unnecessary; instead, we maintained close daily contact on the communication software Discord for questions and elaborations. Our weekly Sprint Planning meetings also functioned as retrospectives on what had been accomplished in the previous week or cycle. This hybrid Scrumban approach allowed us to stay organized, maintain consistent progress, and ensure that each team member could contribute ecectively despite external commitments (Reddy, A, 2015). It helped us balance ﬂexibility with structure, ensuring the project moved forward without sacriﬁcing quality or overburdening any individual team member.

2.4 Tools and Languages 2.4.1 IDE 
 We chose Visual Studio Code (VSCode) (Microsoft, n.d.) for developing the web application due to it being a baseline for .NET development as well as its versatility and powerful features. It is an integrated development environment (IDE) which supports a wide array of languages and frameworks. This IDE also features a vast selection of plugins and extensions for further extending the platform according to project speciﬁc needs. Our backend module is an ASP .NET Core application which utilizes the programming language C#. For this purpose, it requires the relevant C#, C# Dev Kit and .NET Install Tool extensions from Microsoft for compilation, solution exploring and unit testing, and SDK management.  Furthermore, VSCode ocers a solid extension for React development called ES7+ React/Redux snippets and Prettier for automatic code formatting. Through the integrated command line tool (CLI) it provides an easy way to test running both frontend and backend simultaneously. Lastly, the integration of git and GitHub makes committing, pushing and branch handling an integrated part of the development process.

2.4.2 Backend 
 ASP .NET Core (Microsoft, n.d.) is a modern, platform independent and high-performing framework which is well suited as a backend API server for our project. It provides a modular and ﬂexible architecture, making it easy to build RESTful APIs using controllers and routing. With Entity Framework Core, we can handle database operations eciciently, and Identity gives built-in support for authentication and authorization, including roles and potential multi-factor authentication (MFA).  Since we used SQLite, we could utilize ASP .NET Core’s simple conﬁguration for model binding and database structuring. Our APIs are secured using Bearer Tokens, stored in HTTP-only cookies, and we use Axios for frontend communication and API calling. We also conducted integration and unit testing, which ensured reliability, and since ASP .NET Core is optimized for great performance and scalability it gave us a solid foundation for our web application. 2.4.3 Frontend 
    
Figure 5 ASP .NET Core 
Figure 6 React.js

21 / 126  
Our frontend application was built in React (Meta, n.d.), a modern and ecicient JavaScript library for making dynamic user interfaces. As mentioned in the previous chapter, we used Axios for handling API calls to the backend solution, where authentication and sessions are handled securely through HTTP-only cookies instead of localStorage. This elevates security and resilience against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), denying any JavaScript code access to the authentication cookie. One possible drawback of this method could be the development of a potential future native app of the solution, which could see easier, natively implemented API-calling using JSON Web Token (JWT) stored in localStorage. However, this idea was considered outside of the scope of the project. 
 As for styling and layout of the frontend application, we used Bootstrap (Bootstrap, n.d.). This easily gave us a responsive and professional looking design with minimal-ecort implementation. It provides ready-made components that are quick to implement, which in turn, trims down the time from concept to a testable, functioning minimal viable product (MVP). For further visual and UI/UX improvements we enabled Bootstrap’s own Icon package. This makes buttons and clickable elements faster to interpret and helps give the user an instinctive understanding of the elements’ functions. 
Figure 7 Bootstrap

 With React’s component-based architecture we could easily reuse UI elements and handle state in an ecicient way, something which contributed to a clean and maintainable code base. The code in our React application was written in both JavaScript and TypeScript. The code which is the result of previous bachelor’s theses was mostly written in JavaScript. This is an interpreted language which is prone to runtime errors, whereas the functionality now implemented in our own thesis is written in TypeScript. TypeScript shares much of the syntax with regular JavaScript but provides us with beneﬁts such as code completion, and discovery of errors at compile time. In summary, this is a robust, intuitive, secure and user-friendly solution which will scale to meet future needs (Raymond, J, 2024). 2.4.4 Version Control 
 For version control and collaboration, we used git and GitHub. Git let us trace changes, work in parallel on various branches, and easily roll back to earlier versions in case of fatal errors. Although the existing code is presented on GitLab and the ﬁnal solution is to be presented on the same platform, we have chosen to work daily on our own GitHub

repository due to familiarity and ease of use. GitHub works as a centralized platform for storing and sharing the code between the developers. It let us handle feature branching, pull requests and code reviews to organize the development work. Ensuring every developer is always up-to-date and working on the newest code is essential in this process. 2.4.5 Project and Team Management  
 We used Notion as a tool for project management and meeting notes. Through a Kanban board we were able to split the project into phases, track progress, and organize tasks based on states such as Not Started, On-Going, Waiting and Done.  • Not Started state is essentially the backlog of tasks that need to be completed but have not yet been started.  • On-going state includes tasks that have been started in the current phase. • Waiting state is reserved for tasks that for various reasons have been stalled. This could for example be due to reliance on other uncompleted tasks, or because the task is deemed of lower priority than others. • Done state describes the tasks that have been successfully implemented and signed oc on. The other thing we used Notion for was meeting notes. Here, we created templates for Sprint Planning, Daily Standup, Ad Hoc and Weekly Supervision. They were used as follows: 
Figure 10 Notion

• Sprint Planning described the plans for the next sprint, laying out goals, and delegating tasks. • Daily Standup was not much used since we worked well independently and didn’t feel the need for daily meetings, but was meant for laying out what had been done the previous day as well as the goal set for the speciﬁc day. • Ad Hoc was used for meetings that are called on demand. This template included an agenda for the meeting, talking points and to-dos as a result of the meeting. • Weekly Supervision helped to keep track of the weekly supervisory meeting with the faculty. It included the agenda, talking points and resolutions to work on. 
 For communication between the developers and for conducting all but the supervision meetings, we used Discord. The tool provided us with an easy way to communicate with each other through a well-featured chat solution, voice calls or video calls. It also allowed for screen sharing and ad hoc document sharing.  
For communication with advisors, clients, previous bachelor groups and testers we used Outlook and Microsoft Teams. These tools provide email and calendar planning

and have proved a useful application for keeping track of correspondence with outside stakeholders. The weekly advisory meetings were conducted in person or in a hybrid solution via Teams, which enabled voice calls or video calls in addition to screen sharing. These two Microsoft applications worked closely together in helping us keep track of appointments and correspondence. 2.4.6 Integration Testing 
We primarily used Swagger, the built-in API exploration and documentation tool provided by ASP .NET Core, to test our API in development mode. Swagger ocered an interactive interface where we viewed all available endpoints, inspected required parameters, and directly sent HTTP requests such as GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE. Its simple visual structure, organized by controller and endpoint with color-coded HTTP methods, made it easy to navigate and understand how the API was designed. This helped us quickly validate that endpoints were accessible, returned the expected responses, and handled dicerent inputs correctly. It also served as live documentation, making it easier to communicate the API structure during development. Although we did not implement automated tests or formal test scripts, Swagger played an essential role in ensuring the backend behaved as intended before connecting it to the frontend. 2.5 Project Diary For our project diary, we utilized Notion, a versatile tool that allowed us to organize and track our project progress ecectively. We created custom templates for documenting key meetings, ensuring consistency and clarity in our records.  
Figure 13 Swagger

Through these notes we could easily keep track of dates and who attended the meetings, talking points and decision-making processes. Furthermore, Notion allowed for easy delegation of tasks and tracking of responsibilities and workload.  2.6 Unit Testing Unit testing is an essential part of software development and contributes towards assuring that each individual method functions as intended. In our project we have included unit testing as part of our methodology to accomplish a more stable and maintainable code for the application. The focus has been to test backend functionality in ASP .NET Core, with special emphasis on the ProductsController, which makes handling product information smooth and reliable for the users of the app. 2.6.1 Overview of Unit Testing Unit testing is a method of testing where individual units of code – typically individual methods or classes – are tested in isolation from one another and the rest of the system as a whole. The purpose of which is to discover errors early, enhancing the quality of the code and ensuring changes do not introduce new errors. Unit testing also makes it easier to refactor code as it provides insurance of the functionality remaining intact.  Among the beneﬁts of unit testing are: • Early discovery of errors during development. • Better code quality through clearer structuring and modularization. • Increased resilience to refactoring and further development. • Documentation of expected behavior for the code. 2.6.2 Testing Frameworks and Tools For unit testing of the backend, we utilized the testing framework xUnit, in combination with Moq for mocking dependencies such as repositories and UserManager, and asserting return values. This allows us to isolate individual components and simulate dicerent scenarios without requiring an actual database or authentication system. To ensure comprehensive testing, we have:

27 / 126  
• Followed AAA (Arrange-Act-Assert) pattern for clarity and consistency. • Mocked dependencies to isolate functionality and avoid reliance on external services. • Used assertions to validate expected outputs. • Tested dicerent user roles to verify authorization and access control. • Simulated exceptions to ensure proper error handling. 2.6.3 Code Coverage and Implementation In our implementation of tests for the ProductsController, we have focused on reaching 100% code coverage. This means that all methods and control structures have been thoroughly tested, covering various ﬂow control paths such as successful responses, empty results, authorization failures, and error handling. Figure 14 provides an example of a unit test for retrieving all products, showcasing how we validate dicerent scenarios to ensure comprehensive coverage.

28 / 126  
 Figure 14 Unit Test - Retrieving all products 
2.6.4 Results of Unit Testing Through unit testing, we have ensured that the backend logic is reliable, maintainable, and resilient to future changes. By achieving 96.43% code coverage for the ProductsController, we have validated the correctness of business logic, role-based authorization, and error handling mechanisms. This contributed to a more robust application, reducing the likelihood of defects and improving long-term maintainability. 2.7 User Testing 2.7.1 Purpose and Goals The purpose of user testing is to identify usability issues, evaluate new features, and ensure that our design meets the user’s needs. By having users test a prototype relatively early in the project, we were able to locate areas that needed improvement

29 / 126  
before too much time and resources were invested in parts that did not work as intended. Our goal for user testing was to gather valuable insights on how to improve the web application, ensuring that it functions as intended. 2.7.2 Testing Plan In our project, we planned for three rounds of user testing. The tests focused on the role of producers, speciﬁcally examining authentication and authorization, as well as the usability of the Products page. The main goal was to determine if the user stories for the producer deﬁned in Appendix B could be deemed successful. 2.7.3 Scope and Goals The scope and goals of the user testing can be deﬁned with four dicerent aspects: 1. Authentication Process. Here the user was asked to test dicerent aspects of logging in as a user account. The goal of these tests was to validate that users can log in and log out, as well as accomplish relevant tasks related to logging in, such as registering a new user. 2. Account Page Functionality. Here the user would inspect the account page, which contains details for the user account. The goal was to conﬁrm that the user account data was displayed properly, and in a manner that is understandable for the users. 3. CRUD Functionality on the “Products” Page. What we wanted to achieve with these tests was to verify tasks related to creating, reading, updating and deleting product entries that were linked to their account works as intended. 4. Product Calculator Functionality. In the calculator, the goals were to test if the calculator had an intuitive layout and functionality, so that users can enter the information needed and get the information regarding EFSA health claims that they seek, either when creating and saving a new recipe or updating an existing one. 2.7.4 Participants For the ﬁrst round of user testing, we had one participant, a fellow student at OsloMet. They did not have experience with the NORtritious platform but possessed a good

30 / 126  
technical understanding of websites and their common functionalities. For the second round of user testing, a domain expert participated, who was already familiar with the project's purpose and had experience with previous iterations of the NORtritious calculator. The advantage of using a domain expert is their ability to identify functionality issues and their incentive to make the platform intuitive for future personal use. The use of expert users is also recommended when selecting appropriate test participants (Myers, Sandler, & Badgett, 2011). The results of the user tests are discussed in Chapters 4.1.7 and 4.2.6. We initially planned for more rounds of user testing, but due to the second user test being postponed multiple times, the following rounds of testing was deemed not feasible to complete in time. This is discussed more in detail in chapter 4. 2.7.5 Preparation and Environment Several preparations were made to ensure a structured and controlled environment for the user tests. The ﬁrst draft of the web application was ready for testing, with several test accounts created, each with dicerent roles. These accounts included test products to simulate a real production environment. Participants were only available digitally, so the web application was hosted online using GitLab. Communication with participants was facilitated via Zoom or Teams. The tasks were based on the user stories related to the producer role (User stories #1-12) in Appendix B. 2.7.6 Test Procedure The time allotted for the user tests was one hour. Part of the reason for a one-hour session was to respect the participant's time. In order to ensure that the testing would be completed in that time slot, it was important to have a speciﬁc test scenario and tasks. The tasks were given priority based on importance, ranging from 1 as the most important, to 3 as the least important. This was crucial in deciding beforehand which tasks should be prioritized, should we be pressed on time. The test scenario was meant to mirror the way a normal interaction with a web application is conducted. This meant that the user would start by registering an account and logging in. Then they would inspect and interact with their account page. Afterwards they would enter the “Products” page, where they would interact with their product in multiple ways and also

31 / 126  
enter the calculator to update or create a new recipe. Finally, the participant would log out of the web application. The test procedure was completed as three main steps: 1. Introduction and Context: The group shortly presented the project and what the purpose of the user testing was. The participant was given a username and password which they used. The participants were asked to perform the task to the best of their ability but were open to asking questions should the instructions or tasks prove challenging to interpret. We would also ask the participant to “think aloud” during the testing, so it was easier for the group to register if the design of the web application was intuitive given their perception of the tasks. 2. Perform Tasks: The participant would try to perform the tasks listed in the user stories for the producer role listed in the appendix. Meanwhile, the group would observe and take notes regarding quantitative data, such as time used for dicerent tasks, number of errors or how many times the participant asked for help or clariﬁcation. The group would also take notes regarding qualitative data, this being comments the participant made during the testing or unexpected behavior occurring during the testing. 3. Feedback: After the tasks were completed, we asked the participants to explain how they experienced the testing and be open to voice their opinion on what they think worked well, and what they felt needed to be improved. 2.8 Ethical Considerations 2.8.1 User Testing Consent For the NORtritious platform, we conducted user testing to gather feedback for improvements. Participants tested the application and provided valuable insights. Each participant signed a consent form that explained the purpose of the testing and outlined their rights.

32 / 126  
2.8.2 Participant Rights Participants agreed to share their feedback to help improve the application, with the assurance that their information would be kept conﬁdential and secure. They had the right to withdraw from the testing at any time, with the guarantee that their data would be anonymized should they choose to leave. The data collection and processing were compliant with the guidelines set by SIKT, as we have obtained approval for handling personal data according to their standards (SIKT, n.d.).  For more information, please refer to the notiﬁcation form for personal data in the references.

3 Application Documentation This chapter outlines how users interact with the system through registration, login, and product management. It begins by explaining the process of creating an account and logging in, including helpful features that guide users through registration. Certain actions, such as saving products, require authentication, but the key feature nutritional calculator is available to all users. This allows anyone to explore and analyze nutritional data without logging in.  The development process and work done through all iterations are laid out in this chapter. It is built up by iteration and sub-sections highlighting the development through key phases and parts of the application. 4.1 First Iteration 4.1.1 Setting Up the Backend and Business Logic In the early stages of the project, establishing a stable and secure backend was prioritized. The goal was to create a backend architecture that could support a full-stack system with clearly deﬁned responsibilities, ecicient data handling, and robust authentication mechanisms. This backend would serve as the foundation for all business logic, data storage, role-based access control, and secure communication with the frontend. We chose ASP .NET Core 8 as the backend framework, due to its maturity and long-term support, strong security practices, and seamless integration with authentication and identity services.

42 / 126  
ASP .NET Core 8 ocered a highly modular and scalable structure with good support for RESTful APIs, dependency injection, middleware pipelines, and Entity Framework Core. By leveraging these features, we were able to lay a solid foundation that could scale with the system’s complexity and remain maintainable throughout development. The decision to use this version of .NET ensured that we had access to performance improvements and modern conventions, while also maintaining compatibility and ensuring said long-term support. 4.1.1.1 Architectural Structure and Separation of Concerns To ensure maintainability and clarity in the backend codebase, we chose the Model-View-Controller (MVC) architectural pattern. Although our application was API-driven and did not render server-side views, the MVC structure helped separate the concerns of routing, business logic, and data access. Controllers were responsible only for handling incoming HTTP requests and returning appropriate responses. All business logic was handled by the controllers, while data access was delegated to repositories, enabling loose coupling between layers and supporting future unit testing and reusability. This separation was further enforced through the use of dependency injection, which is natively supported in ASP .NET Core. Every controller received its dependencies (e.g., repositories or services such as logging and Identity’s UserManager) through constructor injection, which made the codebase both cleaner and easier to test. The startup process in Program.cs included the registration of all necessary services, database contexts, and repositories, ensuring that application components were consistently and predictably initialized. 4.1.1.2 Data Models

The choice of SQLite was driven by its lightweight nature and ease of use during early development and testing. It does not require a running database server and integrates smoothly with EF Core, making it ideal for prototyping and team collaboration. We managed database schema changes using EF Core Migrations. This allowed us to track the evolution of our data structures over time, apply incremental changes to the

46 / 126  
From the outset, we deﬁned a role-based access strategy that would enforce authorization rules based on the user’s responsibilities. We introduced three predeﬁned roles in the system: Admin, Researcher, and Producer. Each role was assigned a unique set of permissions, and this was reﬂected both in the API structure and the authorization policies deﬁned in the application, as shown in Table 6. Admins were given full access rights, including the ability to manage all products. Producers could add, edit and delete their own product entries but were restricted from accessing data belonging to others. Researchers had read-only access to product information and no ability to modify data. These constraints were enforced using ASP .NET Core’s “[Authorize]” attribute in combination with role-based policies. By applying these annotations at the controller or endpoint level, we ensured that only users with the proper role could access or manipulate resources. During application startup, a dedicated role seeding function ensured that these roles were created in the Identity system if they did not already exist. In the case of for example the API for fetching products from the server, something which every user had the right to access, we had to implement if-statements to dicerentiate which products a user could access. That is, while all roles had access to the API, if the active user was Producer they would have access to their own products, whereas if the active user was Admin they would have access to all.

4.1.1.4 Secure Session Management 
 Figure 23 Conﬁguring application cookie service settings To ensure secure user authentication, we adopted cookie-based authentication using HTTP-only cookies, as implemented in Figure 23. This approach allowed the backend to maintain the user’s session without exposing tokens to the frontend JavaScript layer. Compared to token-based storage in localStorage or sessionStorage, using HTTP-only cookies signiﬁcantly reduces the attack surface for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. These kinds of attacks can potentially be severely damaging and involve malicious scripts accessing session tokens and potentially performing actions on behalf of the user without them knowing.

48 / 126  
We explicitly conﬁgured cookies with the SameSite=None and Secure ﬂags to support usage across dicerent domains (e.g., when developing frontend and backend on separate ports) while still maintaining transport-layer security via HTTPS. These conﬁgurations ensured compatibility with modern browsers while also preventing cross-site request forgery (CSRF) and session hijacking attacks. Both of which involve unlawfully acquiring a user’s session token to gain unauthorized access to someone else’s user data and accounts. Because ASP .NET Core Identity integrates seamlessly with cookie-based authentication, we were able to reuse much of the built-in security infrastructure while maintaining full control over login, logout, and registration endpoints. All authentication and session management were handled server-side, meaning that the frontend did not need to store or manipulate any authentication credentials directly. That said, running the frontend and backend on dicerent ports essentially means the application runs on dicerent domains. This approach relied on the browser permitting third-party cookies, which in some browsers is often referred to as cross-site tracking. While it required lowering cookie security settings during development, it simpliﬁed the application’s security model and enhanced overall robustness. In production, however, it ocers a highly secure and deeply integrated solution running on dicerent paths within the same domain. 4.1.1.5 Logging with Serilog 
 Figure 24 Conﬁguring Serilog application service for logging and debugging

In order to monitor the backend and capture runtime issues, we implemented Serilog as our logging framework, as shown in Figure 24. Serilog is a powerful structured logging library for .NET applications and provides a clear and customizable output format for logs. We conﬁgured Serilog to write to the log ﬁles and formatted messages to include log level, timestamps, and contextual information, which made it easier to identify and troubleshoot problems. By conﬁguring the minimum log level to Information, lower-level logs such as Debug and Trace messages were omitted, reducing noise while still retaining meaningful operational insights. Additionally, routine Entity Framework SQL command logs were ﬁltered out to keep the logs concise. In the development environment, structured logging provided greater transparency into role enforcement making it easier to trace and verify system behavior. 4.1.1.6 API Development Once the backend foundation was fully established, we proceeded to implement the RESTful API endpoints that would allow for communication between the frontend and the server. These endpoints served as the bridge connecting the data stored in the backend database with the user interface rendered by the React application. Our initial focus was to develop the core CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations necessary for managing products. These endpoints were designed to allow authorized users to perform essential data manipulation tasks, with access strictly controlled by role-based authorization policies to ensure data integrity and prevent unauthorized usage. 
 Figure 25 Example of role authorization restrictions on API endpoints In alignment with the system’s role structure, each endpoint was carefully annotated with [Authorize(Roles = " ... ")] (Figure 25) to enforce access restrictions. For example, only

50 / 126  
users with the Producer role were permitted to create or update products, while Researchers were granted read-only access. The Admin role retained full permissions, including the ability to update and delete any and all records. This access model ensured that each endpoint operated within the intended scope of the user’s permissions. Beyond product management, we developed a dedicated controller and set of API endpoints for user and account management. These included endpoints for user registration, fetching user information, proﬁle updates, and password changes. We also implemented an API for proﬁle picture upload which ensures random ﬁle naming and the deletion of any old proﬁle picture to avoid bloating the application with orphaned data and ﬁles. Each endpoint was implemented with a strong emphasis on input validation and security best practices, ensuring that only well-formed and authorized requests were processed by the server. Data Transfer Objects (DTOs) were set up to form incoming and outgoing data and were supplemented with Data Annotations to apply constraints such as required ﬁelds. To further strengthen the reliability and maintainability of the backend, Serilog was integrated into the application’s API methods. This allowed for the capturing of all relevant events, such as HTTP requests, warnings, and errors. This setup was especially helpful when diagnosing issues like database exceptions or unauthorized access attempts. Furthermore, special attention was paid to how responses were logged and returned to the client. Successful operations were marked with clear codes like “200 OK” for general success, “201 Created” when a new resource was successfully created or updated, and “204 No Content” when a resource was deleted without returning a body. Errors and exceptional cases were logged as warnings or errors, and were categorized accordingly:  • “400 Bad Request” for invalid input. • “401 Unauthorized” when authentication was required but missing or invalid. • “403 Forbidden” when a user was authenticated but lacked the necessary role to access a resource.  • “404 Not Found” when a requested resource did not exist.

51 / 126  
• “500 Internal Server Error” when an unexpected issue occurred on the server. By combining clear and appropriate use of HTTP status codes with detailed and contextual logging we could monitor backend behavior and easier see what part of the system raised an error and what triggered it. This also ensured smooth integration with the frontend, which could rely on consistent and predictable responses for both success and error scenarios. Serilog’s structured logging ultimately became a vital part of our development and debugging workﬂow, saving us valuable time. To streamline both development and testing, the project integrated Swagger for API documentation. Swagger automatically generated interactive documentation based on the API’s structure and annotations. This feature allowed developers to test endpoints directly from a browser interface, view expected request formats, and inspect response schemas. As a result, the development team was able to iterate rapidly on the APIs, verify functionality without relying on the frontend, and ensure that the backend was well-documented for future reference. Through the implementation of these RESTful APIs, the backend was transformed from a foundational structure into a fully operational service layer. With secure, validated, and role-aware endpoints in place, the backend was now capable of serving real-time data to the frontend, enabling the application to function as intended. 4.1.2 Setting Up the React Vite Frontend Alongside backend development, establishing a well-integrated frontend environment was a key part of our further project work. for validation without any preliminary checks on the frontend. This approach, while straightforward, resulted in unnecessary API calls when users entered obviously incorrect passwords, which added a slight delay in the user experience as API calls tend to be among the slowest actions in a web application. It also exposed the system to potential abuse by making backend requests even in cases where basic validation could have been performed on the frontend, such as checking password length or ensuring that passwords contained a mix of characters. However, at this stage, the focus was on ensuring the backend logic and authentication ﬂow worked correctly before implementing more sophisticated client-side validation. 
 Figure 35 Basic browser input type validation for required ﬁelds On the frontend, browsers provide a degree of validation for form ﬁelds based on the type of input ﬁeld deﬁned and whether the required attribute is speciﬁed. For example, when a password ﬁeld is deﬁned as an input of type password, the browser will ensure that the user’s input is hidden behind dots or asterisks, adding a layer of visual security. If the ﬁeld is marked as required, the browser will prevent the form from being submitted unless it contains some value, alerting the user to the missing input (Figure 35) before any server-side validation takes place. Additionally, when the input type is speciﬁed as email, browsers will automatically check if the entered text matches a basic email pattern (i.e., username@domain.com). While this form of validation is helpful for catching basic issues, it is not enough to ensure the security and integrity of the password ﬁeld. It mainly serves as a way to guide the user and prevent simple errors, such as forgetting to ﬁll in a required ﬁeld or entering an invalid email address.

4.1.5 Health Claims Structuring There are currently 261 dicerent health claims which are authorized by EFSA (European Commission, n.d.-a). The conditions for using these health claims vary from being highly complex to relatively simple. For instance, to use the following health claim regarding carbohydrate-electrolyte solutions: “. . .  contribute to the maintenance of endurance performance during prolonged endurance exercise”, a number of speciﬁc requirements must be met: “In order to bear the claim carbohydrate-electrolyte solutions should contain 80 350 kcal/L from carbohydrates, and at least 75 % of the energy should be derived from carbohydrates which induce a high glycaemic response, such as glucose, glucose polymers and sucrose. In addition, these beverages should contain between 20 mmol/L (460 mg/L) and 50 mmol/L (1,150 mg/L) of sodium, and have an osmolality between 200 330 mOsm/kg water” (European Commision, n.d.-b). By contrast, the following claim for calcium: “ ... is needed for the maintenance of normal teeth” has a much simpler condition: “The claim may be used only for food which is at least a source of calcium as referred to in the claim SOURCE OF [NAME OF VITAMIN/S] AND/OR [NAME OF MINERAL/S] as listed in the Annex to Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006” (European Commision, n.d.-b). Given that the conditions for using EFSA Health Claims are varied in complexity and structure, it was important for us to prioritize health claims which shared a similar structure in its conditions, so that we could implement as many claims as possible given the available time and scope of this project. In addition, we chose to implement health claims for nutrients which are common, such as vitamins and minerals.  In order to have a solution for handling the addition or deletion of health claims in the future in a ﬂexible manner, it was important to create a solution which was both sustainable and scalable over time. We chose to convert the health claims and their

68 / 126  
associated conditions or requirements from the Excel format provided by the European Commission (European Commision, n.d.-b) into to a structured JSON format. 
 Figure 42 JSON structure of EFSA Health Claims Each nutrient is represented as a separate object in the JSON ﬁle (Figure 42), and each object contains all associated health claims along with their conditions. In each claim, the necessary conditions are included. Many claims share structural elements such as the "source_of" requirement, which made it easier to generalize how these are processed within the application. This approach enables the NORtritious calculator to dynamically check whether a product meets the criteria to legally use a health claim, without hardcoding speciﬁc rules into the application logic.  Structuring the claims in a JSON format has shown to have several beneﬁts: • Scalability: New nutrients and claims can easily be added. • Consistency: Ensures all conditions are validated in a similar manner. • Maintainability: Regulatory changes can be handled by updating the JSON data, without requiring code changes. 4.1.6 Health Claims Component The ﬁrst attempt at implementing health claims (Figure 43) consisted of using bootstrap cards to display the given claims of an ingredient. If the password did not meet the necessary requirements set by ASP .NET Core Identity, the server would respond with a validation error. While functional, this approach led to several usability and performance issues. Most notably, users would only receive feedback after submitting the form, which created a frustrating user experience. Furthermore, every invalid attempt generated an unnecessary API call, which placed avoidable load on the backend.

 Figure 51 Frontend password validation and display of failing requirements To address this, we implemented a client-side validation mechanism that mirrors the same password rules enforced on the server. This allowed us to validate passwords locally before sending any data to the server, resulting in faster feedback to the user and fewer server requests. Our goal was to create a validation system that was both user-friendly and aligned with the security requirements already deﬁned by Identity. We began by deﬁning the password policy explicitly in a JavaScript service function called validatePassword. This function checks that the password meets the following criteria:  • At least length of 8 characters.

78 / 126  
• At least 6 unique characters. • At least one uppercase letter. • At least one lowercase letter. • At least one number. • At least one special character.  The function returns an array of descriptive error messages, as shown in Figure 51, based on which criteria are not fulﬁlled, and if no errors are raised, it returns an empty array. The function return can be checked for its array length to determine whether a validation has passed or not.  
 Figure 52 Password requirements helper popover during user registration To further improve usability, we also created a small, reusable React component called PasswordSpecs. This component displays a tooltip-like popover when the user hovers over or focuses on an information icon. The popover outlines the password requirements in a clear and concise bullet-point list, shown in Figure 52. It was important to us that users be aware of the password rules before they even begin typing, so this component served as a visual reminder of what is expected, reducing confusion and helping users create valid passwords on the ﬁrst try. By implementing both the validation logic and the visual helper, we not only enhanced the user experience but also ensured consistency between the frontend and backend.

4.2.2 Nøkkelhullet Validations During the second iteration, we discovered several inconsistencies in how these thresholds were both deﬁned and validated. As a result, we began correcting and implementing the correct thresholds as deﬁned by law, speciﬁcally referencing the "Forskrift om frivillig merking av næringsmidler med Nøkkelhullet" (Lovdata, n.d.).
 Figure 53 Nøkkelhullet validation results pane We began by reviewing and correcting the nutritional requirements stored in the kravNokkelhullet.jsx ﬁle, which acts as a central conﬁguration for displaying Nøkkelhullet criteria in the results pane of the application. This ﬁle deﬁnes a mapping between product categories and thresholds for macronutrients such as fat, saturated fat, added and natural sugars, ﬁber, protein and salt. For each category, the thresholds are speciﬁed using a simple object structure that enables us to display and access these constraints dynamically. For example, a category might specify “added sugars must not exceed 1 g/100 g” , while leaving other nutrient ﬁelds as null if no requirement applies. During this iteration, we updated these values for categories 1 through 18 to ensure they accurately reﬂected the regulations as deﬁned. We also cleaned up the visuals of the results pane (Figure 53) to better deliver the results without overwhelming the user with bold text, underlining and paragraph misalignment.

That said, updating the display values alone was not sucicient. The application also includes a set of validation ﬁles, one for each of the Nøkkelhullet product categories, all of which individually both validates and renders the results for the given category. These validation modules play a critical role during product evaluation, determining if a product can be certiﬁed with the Nøkkelhullet label based on its nutritional contents. In the initial version of the application, some of these category ﬁles contained the same outdated or incorrect validation logic as the kravNokkelhullet.jsx ﬁle, such as using the wrong thresholds or skipping important checks. In this iteration, we systematically went through the ﬁrst 18 category validation ﬁles and aligned their logic with the ocicial Nøkkelhullet requirements.  
 Figure 54 Validation of combined added and natural sugars Another important ﬁx was made to the nutritional calculator where, initially, the application assumed that the “carbohydrates” input represented the total sugar content of a product. This was incorrect, as total carbohydrates also include starches and ﬁbers, not just sugars. According to the Nøkkelhullet rules, validation must consider both natural sugars and added sugars separately and in total. To address this, we modiﬁed the calculator to sum the natural and added sugars explicitly, providing a more accurate total sugar value (Figure 54). This correction ensures that, where applicable, products are only approved if they meet the total sugars requirements.

To improve performance and state management, we introduced an authentication context in React, reducing redundant API calls and enabling more ecicient handling of user state. Based on feedback, we

88 / 126  
made several adjustments to improve clarity and usability: nutrition and health claims were separated into distinct columns in the product table view, making them easier to dicerentiate. We also updated the naming of categories and groups to align with the terminology used in the original calculator, ensuring consistency. Lastly, we added helper popovers to categories requiring special considerations, for instance, clarifying that nutritional data for bread mixes should reﬂect the prepared product. This provided clearer guidance to users where relevant. 4.3.1 Authentication State Using Context Previously, user authentication was managed locally within individual components. This meant that any component needing to check if the user was logged in, retrieve their role, or display their name had to implement its own logic, often involving direct API calls or duplicated state. As our application began to grow in complexity, especially with conditionally displayed components, it became clear that this decentralized approach was not scalable. To solve this, we implemented a centralized AuthContext, which moved all authentication-related logic and state into one global provider. 
 Figure 62 Conﬁguring authentication context for the entire frontend application

89 / 126  
First, we had to wrap the application in the AuthProvider, as shown in Figure 62, so that all components could access the context. This change was fairly straightforward but essential. Without it, the custom useAuth hook would throw errors due to missing context. From there, we began replacing local state and logic in each component that had previously managed authentication manually. This included removing any individual API calls to fetch user data or login status and instead using the centralized context values like isLoggedIn, role, and name. Additionally, components that previously relied on useState or useEcect to manage user sessions or display messages had to be updated to use the shared context. In several places, especially in navigation component, proﬁle pages, and login/register forms we refactored props and state variables. This required careful coordination to ensure that no functionality was lost or broken during the migration. Although the AuthContext signiﬁcantly improved the architecture, integrating it was relatively intrusive due to how entangled authentication logic had become with UI and routing behavior in our earlier code. 
 Figure 63 Updated login with new context handlers for login and registration

90 / 126  
We also updated our login and registration forms to work with the new context-based handlers, handleLogin and handleRegistration (Figure 63). This meant removing internal state and form submission logic from the pages themselves and delegating that responsibility to the context. In doing so, the pages became more focused on UI and presentation, while the logic of managing credentials and server communication was isolated inside AuthContext. One particularly challenging aspect was aligning the forms’ behavior with the asynchronous nature of these handlers, such as waiting for a boolean response to determine whether to navigate or show an error. These edge cases had to be carefully handled to prevent wrong states. 
 Figure 64 Conﬁguring function to fetch authenticated user on page load We also introduced logic to fetch the current user session automatically on page load using a useEcect (Figure 64) inside the AuthProvider. This ensures that if the user has a valid cookie, their session is restored without needing to re-enter credentials.  Perhaps one of the most notable changes was the simpliﬁcation of logout behavior. Instead of manually resetting values and redirecting users in several components, we now rely on the shared handleLogout function. This not only makes logout more reliable

91 / 126  
and consistent but also allows for additional logic to be placed in one location, such as resetting state. Finally, with the user’s role stored centrally, it became much easier to implement role-based UI, conditionally render components and work with permission-based access control. While the initial implementation required us to touch almost every part of the application, the beneﬁts include a far more maintainable codebase. 4.3.2 Table View Columns A key usability issue identiﬁed through testing and user feedback was the confusion between nutritional claims and health claims. 6 Reﬂection 6.1 Choice of Work Method In the beginning of the project, we created a detailed and phase-oriented development plan, supported by a work method inspired by Scrumban as described in Chapter 2. We aimed to work in bi-weekly sprints, with sprint planning sessions at the beginning of the week, and clearly deﬁned tasks distributed across the team. In the initial phases, we followed this structure closely, and the method helped create momentum and gave everyone a clear overview of responsibilities and deadlines. For a while, we were ahead of schedule, the plan served its purpose well, and we were able to move forward according to schedule. As the project progressed, however, our ability to follow the original plan began to loosen. This was primarily due to extensive early development, especially in the ﬁrst iteration, which required substantial setup work for both backend and frontend. Combined with diciculties in scheduling meetings with our user tester, these delays had a ripple ecect that moved user testing and made our workﬂow more ﬂuid. Instead of structured weekly meetings, we increasingly relied on ongoing communication through chat and conference calls and held meetings ad-hoc as needed. This gave us ﬂexibility in a busy period, and since we all had a good understanding of the project and what needed to be done, we could choose tasks based on priority and availability without much formal planning. Even though we moved away from the formalities of the method, we still largely followed the intentions and broader lines of the original development plan. The biggest deviation was the reduced number of user tests, which were halved from the original plan. Apart from that, we were able to keep momentum and deliver the functionality we had anticipated. In the end, adapting our work method helped us stay productive even when the plan no longer completely matched the realities of our schedule. This ﬂexibility turned out to be essential for completing the project.

100 / 126  
6.2 Choice of Technologies Initially, we made deliberate choices regarding technology, with an architecture based on ASP .NET Core for the backend, React for the frontend, and SQLite for the database. These choices were motivated by familiarity, simplicity of setup, and a good ﬁt for a lightweight web application. In general, the technology stack served us well. Entity Framework streamlined data access and migrations, while React provided the ﬂexibility to create a responsive user interface. However, the integration of Identity for authentication, combined with cookie-based token handling, provided some early challenges. Ensuring secure token storage and handling CORS policies correctly took more time than expected, particularly because we were working across two separate projects (frontend and backend) on dicerent domains during development. Setting up the communication layer between backend and frontend was another complex task. While building the API endpoints was straightforward, testing them thoroughly and ensuring correct request handling on the frontend side was a time-consuming ecort. Additionally, the initial conﬁguration of HTTPS redirection, especially in development, caused some minor issues in relation to the set CORS policy. 6.3 User Testing and Feedback User testing was a core part of our original plan, with multiple scheduled testing sessions throughout the development process. However, due to scheduling diciculties and time constraints, we only completed half of the planned sessions. The limited scope of user involvement likely impacted our ability to optimize usability and accessibility in more detail. While this limited the amount of direct feedback we received, the feedback we did gather proved valuable. Therefore, in future projects, we would prioritize getting early feedback, even with rough prototypes or minimal viable products (MVP), to identify issues earlier.

7 Conclusion The NORtritious project set out to extend an existing nutrition calculator by integrating it into a complete web application. All deﬁned goals have been successfully achieved. The most signiﬁcant of which were the integration of the standalone calculator into a full-stack web application, enabling food producers and researchers to access and utilize the tool through a secure, web application interface. The system now supports role-based functionality, allowing Food Producers to create and manage products and Researchers to evaluate existing ones. Support for EFSA Health Claims was added, allowing the platform to handle micronutrients such as vitamins and minerals in accordance with ocicial European Union regulations. In addition to this new functionality, faulty validation logic in previously implemented nutrition claims (categories 1 through 18, totaling 32 individual claims) was corrected to ensure accurate and compliant evaluations. The web application was built using React and ASP .NET Core, with a secure backend and structured API layer. User authentication and authorization were implemented using HTTP-only cookies to enhance security. Basic user proﬁle functionality was introduced, enabling users to view and update personal information. Furthermore, a full CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) feature set for nutritional products was developed, including the ability to save and manage nutritional data for each product entry. Several bugs and inconsistencies inherited from earlier iterations were ﬁxed, and the user interface was reﬁned to improve usability and clarity. In conclusion, the NORtritious platform has been made into a reliable, secure, and user-friendly tool that meets all original project objectives: integrating the calculator, correcting validation logic, implementing health claims, supporting user authentication, authorization through user roles, and product CRUD. The system is now set to support food producers and researchers in the development and evaluation of healthier food products.

This is used to manage identity-related tasks like ﬁnding users and validating credentials. The controller also relies on IAccountRepository which is set up to handle all database queries relating to user authentication. This helps with abstraction of account management logic and further promoting separation of concerns. Lastly, the backend application has set up a Serilog logger service ILogger<AccountController>, which is used to log events of various levels, provided a lower limit of Information level logging. The controller contains the following methods:

105 / 126  
• Register(RegisterRequest request) allows new users to register as either Producers or Researchers. It takes a RegisterRequest containing email, password, and role. If registration is successful via the RegisterAsync() method in the repository, it returns an HTTP 200 OK with a success message. If registration fails, it returns a 400 Bad Request with speciﬁc identity errors. • Login(LoginRequest request) handles user login for all roles. It accepts a LoginRequest containing email and password, and uses the LoginAsync() method from the repository. On successful login, it retrieves the logged-in user and their role, returning a GetUserResponse with basic user info. On failure, it checks for lockout or disallowed login reasons and returns appropriate error messages (e.g., account locked, not conﬁrmed, or invalid credentials). • CheckLogin() is used to verify if the user is currently authenticated. It checks the User.Identity object and returns true if the user is logged in, otherwise false. If any exception occurs during the check, it logs the error and returns a 500 Internal Server Error with a general error message. • GetUserInfo() fetches basic information about the currently logged-in user, including name, email, role, organization number, and proﬁle picture. This method is protected by [Authorize] and logs errors if any issue arises when fetching the user from the database. • AdminRoleTest() is a simple endpoint restricted to users with the “Admin” role. If accessed successfully, it returns a message conﬁrming access. If an exception is thrown, it logs the error and returns a 500 error with a generic failure message. • ListUsersAsync() allows admins to view a list of all registered users by logging them to the console. It uses the ListUsersAsync() method from the repository. On success, it returns a message stating that users have been listed. If an error occurs, it is logged and a 500 error is returned. • Logout() logs out the current user by calling LogoutAsync() from the repository. After a successful logout, it returns a conﬁrmation message. If an error occurs during the process, it logs the error and returns a 500 Internal Server Error. • ChangePasswordAsync(ChangePasswordRequest request) allows authenticated users to change their password. It requires the user’s email, old password, and

new password through a ChangePasswordRequest. If the user is found and the password is successfully changed, it returns an OK message. Otherwise, it returns validation or identity errors with a 400 status. • UpdateUser(UpdateUserRequest request) lets an authenticated user update their Name and OrganizationNumber without changing their email. The new values are taken from an UpdateUserRequest object. The update is logged before and after the operation. If the 7update fails, it logs   88the error and returns a 400 Bad Request with the identity errors.u/_6 • UploadProﬁlePicture(IFormFile ﬁle) allows authenticated users to upload a new proﬁle picture. It ﬁrst validates that a ﬁle has been uploaded and that it has a valid image extension (jpg, jpeg, png, gif). If the ﬁle is invalid i missing, it returns a 400 Bad Request. It then fetches the logged-in user and checks if they already have a proﬁle picture stored—if so, the old image ﬁle is deleted from the server. A unique ﬁle name is generated using the user’s ID and a timestamp, and the new ﬁle is saved in the wwwroot/images/proﬁle_pictures directory. The user’s ProﬁlePicture property is updated with the new image path, and the change is saved to the database. On success, it returns an OK response with the new image URL; otherwise, it logs the error and returns a 500 Internal Server Error with a user-friendly message. The controller contains the following methods: • GetAllProductsAsync() retrieves all products from the database, regardless of the user, and returns them to the client. It is protected by role-based authorization, allowing only Admins, Producers, and Researchers to access it.  • GetProductByIdAsync(int id) retrieves a single product by its ID and returns it. If the product isn’t found, it responds with a 404 Not Found. Like the previous method, it is limited to Admins, Producers, and Researchers through role-based authorization. • GetProductByUserIdAsync() returns products based on the currently authenticated user. If the user is a Researcher or Admin, it returns all products; otherwise, it returns only the products created by that speciﬁc user (typically a Producer). This method dynamically adjusts the result based on the user’s role. • CreateProductAsync(ProductDTO productDTO) allows an authenticated Producer to create a new product. It maps the incoming ProductDTO to a Product entity, associates it with the currently logged-in user, and saves it to the database. It returns the newly created product on success or appropriate error messages on failure. • UpdateProductAsync(int id, ProductDTO productDTO) updates an existing product’s details. Admins can update any product, while Producers can only update their own. The method ensures the product exists, checks ownership if needed, maps new values from the DTO, and saves the changes.

It checks that the ﬁle exists and is of a valid image type (jpg, jpeg, png, or gif), then proceeds to save it (although the saving logic isn’t fully shown in your snippet). The method is accessible to any authenticated user. • UploadProductImage(IFormFile ﬁle) allows an authenticated user to upload an image for a product. It validates the ﬁle type, ensures the upload directory exists, saves the image with a unique ﬁlename, and returns the relative image URL. If the ﬁle is missing, invalid, or an error occurs during upload, appropriate error messages are returned. • DeleteProductImage(ImageDeleteRequest request) deletes an uploaded product image based on the provided image URL. It ensures the ﬁle exists on the server and removes it if found. If the image is not found or deletion fails, it returns a corresponding error message. As a Producer I need to be able to create, calculate and save a new product.      Task for User Testing:  Eng: Please go to the page for creating a new product, ﬁll in the necessary information for the product, calculate the health claims, and save the product. Here, you can use the information for the product you had prepared in advance.  Nor: Vennligst gå til siden for å opprette et nytt produkt, fyll ut nødvendig informasjon for produktet, beregn helsepåstander og lagre produktet. Her kan du bruke informasjonen til produktet du hadde forberedt på forhånd.  
    
    Acceptance Criteria:    Provided authenticated and authorized, the user should be able to click “Calculator” , provide necessary product data, see the calculated claims and click “Save” to create a new product.    
        
    Failure Criteria:    Provided authenticated and authorized:    - The user is not able to locate the calculator page.     - The user locates and navigates to the calculator page but is not able to enter all the product data necessary to create and save a new product on the calculator page.    
        
  Question(s):  Eng:  How did you experience ﬁlling out the information for the product?
